titlestmt.titleproper: A Finding Aid to the Bland Gallery Letters, 1931-1953, in the Archives of American Art
titlestmt.author: Stephanie Ashley

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on 2023-08-24 13:11:14 -0400.

did.abstract: The Bland Gallery letters collection dates from 1931-1953, and comprises 60 items, primarily letters, discussing the collection and sale of miniature portraits.

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: Bland Gallery was an art gallery in New York, New York, that specialized in the purchase and sale of miniatures.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Due to it's small size, the collection is arranged as one series.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The Bland Gallery letters collection dates from 1931-1953, and comprises 60 items, primarily letters, discussing the collection and sale of miniature portraits.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: This collection is open for research. Access to original papers requires an appointment and is limited to the Archives' Washington, D.C. Research Center.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: The bulk of the collection was donated by Jane Cooper Bland, Bland's widow, in 1970. The 1953 letter was donated by Argosy Bookshop in 1958.

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: The collection was microfilmed on Reels D8 and 132 after receipt. The collection was processed and a finding aid prepared by Stephanie Ashley, and was digitized, in 2021.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Correspondence is with John Hill Morgan, discussing the authentication and purchase of eighteenth century American historic engravings and portraits; correspondence with Henry F. du Pont relating to collecting American portraits and naval scenes; correspondence with Josiah K. Lilly, regarding collecting portraits of English and American literary and political figures; and correspondence with David K. E. Bruce, and others. One October 1953 letter is from Albert Deane of Paramount International Films in New York, concerning a possible Gilbert Stuart miniature.
